entries.author: Burkeman, Oliver
entries.source: Why can’t the world’s greatest minds solve the mystery of consciousness?
entries.description: Burkeman's long form article walks through the modern understanding of the problem of consciousness. As part of my research, the text provides insight into how the foundation of knowledge can be applied to contemporary challenges of identity and its associated implications.

entries.author: Westphal, Jonathan
entries.source: Descartes and the Discovery of the Mind-Body Problem.
entries.description: Westphal provides another perspective on the modern view of the mind-body problem and its implications. This text serves as further evidence to the importance of the subject matter and what objections we expect to encounter upon proposing a solution.

entries.author: Blair, Peter
entries.source: What We Are: Mind, Body, and the Dangers of Dualism.
entries.description: Blair opines the Christian view against Cartesian dualism. He asserts the hylemorphic nature of man as the bridge between subjective and objective realities, similar to Gallagher's theory of man as questioning existence.

entries.author: Gallagher, Kenneth T
entries.description: Gallagher provides an overview of the key areas regarding the bipolarity of consciousness and its resolution through the viewpoints of prominent modern philosophers such as Martin Heidegger and Gabriel Marcel.

entries.author: Walker, Percy
entries.source: The Message in the Bottle: How Queer Man Is, How Queer Language Is, and What One Has to Do with the Other
entries.publisher: New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux
entries.chapter: Toward a Triadic Theory of Meaning.
entries.description: Percy complements the notion of the question as irreducible beginning in his work on semiotics and triadic meaning. His principal solution is on language, but his arguments align similarly when the subject is on the nature of curiosity and questioning in man.

entries.author: Ariew, Roger and Eric Watkins
entries.source: Modern philosophy: an anthology of primary sources
entries.chapter: Meditation Three: Concerning God, That He Exists.
entries.description: Ariew and Watkins synthesize the thoughts of modern philosophers and represents Descartes 'Meditations' well. Reviewing the primary source allows for a deeper engagement with the thesis statement.

entries.author: Marcel, Gabriel
entries.source: The Mystery of Being Vol. 1, Reflection & Mystery
entries.chapter: Chapter VI: Feeling as a Mode of Participation.
entries.description: Marcel argues for the the being-by-participation idea to resolve the problem of the mind-body divide. This slots in well with the focus of the paper to address the mind-body problem.

entries.author: Robinson, Howard
entries.description: Robinson systematically categorizes the ambiguity of the mind-body problem into distinct realms within philosophy. This source allows the presentation to precisely address a particular aspect of the mind-body problem with the irreducible beginning as the question.

entries.author: Downing, Lisa
entries.description: Downing synthesizes the thought of Berkeley. Berkeley's contribution to the epistemological realm of idealism is insightful when demonstrating the extremes of the mind-body problem. This data point provides added context and gravitas the point of misaligned epistemologies with regards to man's being and knowledge.

entries.author: Stoljar, Daniel
entries.description: Stoljar showcases the other extreme of the mind-body dualism divide - that which focuses on the consequences of the body-only reality. As with Berkeley's idealism, physicalism demonstrates the opposite extremes of dualism.

entries.author: Fieser, James
entries.description: Fieser's work aids in providing another perspective and further examples to aid in the grasping of the mind-body problem, extolling the arguments both for and against dualism.
